jamie, i think this one is for you.

OK get ready for the explanation ;-)

On the OW form you use to submit an event there is a field called 'strapline' (one sentence) and a field called 'description' (In no more than 300 words please tell us about your event/project)

On the Event itself there there is a 'description' (short description) and a 'body' (long description) field (as well as a 
'strapline' field which seems to have been added more recently; and actually may be confusing things *).

When an event is submitted (via the form) the filed called strapline ('one sentence' on the form) gets stored in the 'description' field (on the event) and the 'description' field ('300 words' on the form) actually gets stored in the 'body' field (on the event).

This isn't as crazy as it sounds, as the OW events share the same fields as the normal events (which don't have a strap line) so what we are saying is take what is labeled as a strapline on the OW event submission form and store it in the description field ('description' is the default field we show as the one line description in search results and the field that Stamen look for when adding events to the map) and store the longer description (In no more than 300 words please tell us about your event/project) in the 'body' field on the event (we use 'body' as it's the default content area of the page and once again the field that Stamen look for when adding events to the map)

What is slightly confusing if that when an event is submitted we store the text the user entered into 'strapline' (one sentence) into *both* the 'description' and 'strapline' field on the event and because of that on export they look the same. 

The solution would actually be to remove the 'strapline' field completely from the actual events (as the data is already duplicated in the 'description' field).

What we have currently is:

 'one sentence/strapline' -> 'description'
 'one sentence/strapline' -> 'strapline'
 '300 words' -> 'body'

Ideally we just need:

 'one sentence/strapline' -> 'description'
 '300 words' -> 'body'

This will mean that when the OW team edit an event in the CMS what they think of as the  'one sentence/strapline' is actually the description field.

Once again the reason for this is that the 'description' and 'body' fields (short test/long text) have special meaning on events and are the fields used in searched and picked up by Stamen for use on the map. If we put a summary line in a new field called 'strapline' it wont' be picked up anywhere.

At the moment we can just ignore it, but would be best to remove the strapline completely and make the OW team aware that the 'one sentence/strapline' is actually the description field in the CMS.

Let me know if it is safe to remove the strap line.

thanks

Jamie

ps. if you look at the two fields in the attached screenshot you'll see that the two fields are being export separately, but this is a red herring, it's simply because the two fields both get populated with the same data when an event is submitted.

Just to throw the cat amongst the pigeons -- are we forgetting the 'challenge' field? Where does that go?

And so in conclusion the reason it's getting exported twice is b/c it's i nthe back end twice?

 _____

> Just to throw the cat amongst the pigeons -- are we forgetting the  
> 'challenge' field? Where does that go?
>

In the 'challenge' field

Splendid. For awhile they were in the strapline field, which is why i was confused.

I don't see any reason why the 'strapline' field is needed. And the OW team will understand if it's just called 'description'. After all - it already is!

comments.value:
Hello

Part of the new 'Share this' feature includes 'Share via email', allowing you to email a page to a friend. 

It actually doesn't seem to be working properly - it's mostly not linked. We have been requested to remove the 'send an email' feature altogether, as it is vulnerable to abuse both by spoofing emails and by injecting rogue code. Please could this be removed?

Many thanks!

Morag

Hi Morag,

1) "It actually doesn't seem to be working properly" in what way? 
Seems to be working perfectly for me..

2) In terms of spoofing emails, we only allow one email to be sent per 
IP address per hour (actually you may be able to send more than one if 
you use web01 and then web02).

3) In terms of 'injecting rogue code' we strip out any HTML mark up 
(or rather escape it) and the email is sent as a plain text so no 
email client should be rendering the HTML, to be extra safe we could 
completely remove the box

Although I do agree that if the service isn't being used much and you 
would rather play it safe (and obviously the less points of attack the 
better) then it may be sensible to remove it completely.

However this does leave the question of what goes in the place of it?

Should we just move the Share on Regit/Digg/Stumble links up the 3rd 
column and leave the rest of the space on the right empty of now?

Jamie

Hello

 

The grab showing the 'Email this page' function not working is attached
- in IE8 the 'Share this page' function is not underlined - so you can't
activate it.

 

Apols, I didn't mean to imply negligence in the way the email
functionality had been set up! I would never do that! It's just that our
IT security people have requested that we disable this type of
functionality across all our websites, and I am merely their mouthpiece
:-(

 

In terms of what goes in the place of it, I agree with moving the Share
on Regit/Digg/Stumble links up the 3rd column and leaving the rest of
the space on the right empty for the moment. 

 

Many thanks!

 

Morag

 

 

 

________________________________
Marking as solved.
